moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be3 a6 7. Bd3 b5
comment: This early ...b7-b5 is a trademark of the Polgar family. They've played it a long time. Judit has played it infrequently in recent years, having switched to the Najdorf-like move-order which Kasparov uses.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be3 a6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nxc6
comment: White trades knights before ...Bc8-b7 to prevent Black her ideal coordination.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be3 a6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nxc6 Qxc6 9. O-O Bb7 10. a3 Nf6 11. Qe2 h5
comment: This is unusual in most Sicilian Defense variations, but normal in this one. Black aligns bishops and queen to aim at Kg1 and then throws forward the king-side pawn and Nf6-g4 to add more pressure.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be3 a6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nxc6 Qxc6 9. O-O Bb7 10. a3 Nf6 11. Qe2 h5 12. f4
comment: I can't imagine why White would allow Nf6-g4 this way. To weaken the dark squares so seriously has to be very bad.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be3 a6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nxc6 Qxc6 9. O-O Bb7 10. a3 Nf6 11. Qe2 h5 12. f4 Ng4 13. Bd2 Bc5+ 14. Kh1 Bd4 15. Rae1 O-O-O
comment: Black has absolutely no weakness White can exploit. This is very nearly winning for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be3 a6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nxc6 Qxc6 9. O-O Bb7 10. a3 Nf6 11. Qe2 h5 12. f4 Ng4 13. Bd2 Bc5+ 14. Kh1 Bd4 15. Rae1 O-O-O 16. Nd1 f5 17. Ba5 Rdf8 18. c3 Ba7 19. e5 g5 20. c4 bxc4 21. Bxc4 gxf4 22. Rf3 Rhg8 23. b4 Nxe5
comment: Nifty. Again the theme is to deflect White's queen away from g2, regardless of the cost.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be3 a6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nxc6 Qxc6 9. O-O Bb7 10. a3 Nf6 11. Qe2 h5 12. f4 Ng4 13. Bd2 Bc5+ 14. Kh1 Bd4 15. Rae1 O-O-O 16. Nd1 f5 17. Ba5 Rdf8 18. c3 Ba7 19. e5 g5 20. c4 bxc4 21. Bxc4 gxf4 22. Rf3 Rhg8 23. b4 Nxe5 24. Qxe5 Qxc4 25. Nb2 Bxf3 26. gxf3 Qc2
comment: Black's play was direct beautifully coordinated and strangely White did nothing to prevent it.
